G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 4.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, §§ 3, 4 and G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the original custody order was issued by this Court and the child resides in this county.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, §§ 3, 4 and G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the original custody order was issued by this Court and the child resides in this county.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The 2018 Custody Order was based on the circumstances then existing and was found by the Court to be in the best interests of the minor child at that time, consistent with G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the principles set forth in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas does not involve a 2018 custody order, but it does articulate the governing Massachusetts principles that custody and removal decisions must be based on the then-existing circumstances and determined according to the best interests of the child under G.L. c. 208. The opinion repeatedly frames both the custody and removal determinations as case‑specific best-interests assessments, aligned with later applications under § 28. Thus, as background authority for the idea that a custody order reflects the child’s best interests at the time it is made, consistent with Yannas, the citation is generally accurate.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that "[a] minor child of divorced parents... shall not... be removed out of this commonwealth... unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders." The words "upon cause shown" mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these "best interests" are to be determined.... The judge was warranted in concluding that physical custody in the wife was in the best interests of each child.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The 2018 Custody Order was based on the circumstances then existing and was found by the Court to be in the best interests of the minor child at that time, consistent with G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the principles set forth in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: Custody of Kali does reaffirm that custody determinations must be made under a "best interests of the child" standard and discusses stability and continuity, but it does not involve G.L. c. 208, § 28, which governs divorce cases, nor does it address a prior "2018 Custody Order" or any temporal framing like "at that time." It interprets G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) for nonmarital children, not § 28, so it cannot be cited as authority that a particular 2018 order under § 28 was based on then‑existing circumstances and the child’s best interests. The proposition therefore over-reads what Kali actually decides and mislocates its statutory context.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard… has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation… General Laws c. 209C, § 10(a), which was enacted in 1986, reflects this trend… The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child.”}

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion is clearly a custody case and repeatedly frames the analysis in terms of the child’s welfare and the impact of domestic violence on the child, consistent with a best‑interests standard. However, in the excerpt provided the court does not expressly state the familiar formula that ‘the paramount consideration is the best interests of the child’; that principle is applied rather than explicitly recited. Thus the case is consistent with and implicitly supports the proposition, but is not a clean textual source for the precise wording.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. . . . The Appeals Court’s remand order is designed to do just that. We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm.

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A modification of a custody order is appropriate where the moving party demonstrates (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior order and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion addresses the standards for making an initial custody award and emphasizes that custody decisions must be based on the best interests and welfare of the child. It does not discuss modification of an existing custody order, nor does it articulate the specific requirement of showing a material and substantial change in circumstances. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the two-part standard for modification of custody orders.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 370\u.proposition: A modification of a custody order is appropriate where the moving party demonstrates (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior order and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 370\u.support_reasoning: The case deals with modification of alimony and child support, not modification of a custody order. While it states that to modify support the petitioner must show a material change of circumstances and discusses the needs of the children and the circumstances of the parents, it does not articulate or apply a two-part standard for modifying custody orders based on best interests of the child. Thus it is not proper authority for the specific custody-modification proposition cited.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 370\u.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28….”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 405–06 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have consistently held that a significant change in a parent’s health or functional capacity, where it affects parenting ability and the child’s safety or welfare, can constitute a material and substantial change warranting modification of custody or parenting time.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The case is a direct appeal from an original divorce judgment deciding initial custody and visitation, not a proceeding to modify an existing custody or parenting-time order based on post-judgment changes. The opinion does not discuss a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances,’ nor any change in a parent’s health or functional capacity as a basis to alter prior custody arrangements. Its custody analysis focuses on best interests, joint vs. sole custody, and parental conflict, not health-based changes warranting modification, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “The husband does not claim that such ‘irrational’ fears of the wife could cause her to become a ‘nonfunctional’ parent and thus render her unfit. See Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. at 627-628; McMahon v. McMahon, 1 Mass. App. Ct. 647, 649 (1973). Nor did he present any evidence showing that the wife’s perception caused ‘“deleterious effect[s]’ on the children and an ‘undermining’ of the custodial relationship,” Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 240 (1981)….”}

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 226\u20.proposition: The best-interests analysis is fact-specific and includes consideration of the child’s safety, emotional development, stability, and the ability of each parent to meet the child’s needs and provide appropriate care and supervision.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 226\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly characterizes the best-interests inquiry as a discretionary, fact-dependent judgment requiring attention to a wide range of evidence. In applying that standard, the court expressly notes consideration of Hugo’s safety, emotional and behavioral vulnerabilities, developmental needs, need for a consistent and predictable environment, stability of each proposed home, and each caregiver’s ability and track record in meeting his special needs and providing appropriate care and supervision. This aligns with the proposition’s description of a fact-specific best-interests analysis encompassing safety, emotional development, stability, and parental capacity to meet the child’s needs.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 226\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’… [T]he judge appropriately considered the personal, educational, psychological, and other support available to each prospective parent to address Hugo’s needs… [and] whether Hugo’s present home itself will provide a stable environment for him.”}

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 190\.proposition: Massachusetts law encourages arrangements that maintain the child’s relationship with both parents, so long as they are consistent with the child’s best interests and safety.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 190\.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on child support calculation, security for support/college expenses, and the standards for modifying legal custody. It does not articulate any general principle that Massachusetts law encourages maintaining a child’s relationship with both parents, nor does it discuss parenting time, visitation, or co‑parenting policies in those terms. The brief custody discussion centers only on the requirement of findings about the child’s best interests, not on encouragement of ongoing relationships with both parents.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 190\.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Massachusetts law encourages arrangements that maintain the child’s relationship with both parents, so long as they are consistent with the child’s best interests and safety.

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 871–73 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: In light of Father’s progressive condition, the Court may craft an order that is flexible and subject to review, to account for further changes in Father’s health and ability to safely parent, consistent with the principles in G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the Court’s broad equitable powers.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal request under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and the application of the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test; it does not discuss crafting flexible, reviewable orders to accommodate a parent’s progressive medical condition or invoke broad equitable powers in that context. While the court cites G.L. c. 208, § 28 regarding modification standards, it does so only to correct the judge’s treatment of ‘changed circumstances’ (remarriage), not to endorse flexible or contingent orders tied to evolving parental health. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, § 60 (‘Upon a complaint after a divorce … the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: In light of Father’s progressive condition, the Court may craft an order that is flexible and subject to review, to account for further changes in Father’s health and ability to safely parent, consistent with the principles in G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the Court’s broad equitable powers.

Heistand v. Heistand, 384 Mass. 20, 26\u.proposition: The Court’s authority to modify custody and parenting-time provisions extends to orders originally entered by agreement of the parties, if the change in circumstances and best-interests standard are satisfied.
Heistand v. Heistand, 384 Mass. 20, 26\u.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of child support (an upward change in weekly payments) following a demonstrated change in the father’s income, and discusses the standard for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28. It does not discuss or analyze modification of custody or parenting-time provisions at all, nor does it address whether such authority extends to orders originally entered by agreement. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition stated.
Heistand v. Heistand, 384 Mass. 20, 26\u.relevant_excerpt: “In the interests of finality this court has conditioned modification upon a demonstrated change in circumstances after entry of the original decree. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). The determination of the extent and palpability of such change, however, lies in large measure within the discretion of the trial judge. … Of the several factors which the judge may consider in modifying a decree for child support, G. L. c. 208, § 28, this court has never required that they be accorded equal weight or conjunctive application.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: The Court also has authority to impose conditions or safeguards on parenting time (including, where appropriate, requirements for supervision, the presence of another responsible adult, or limitations on overnights) as necessary to protect the child’s safety and welfare.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: The Court also has authority to impose conditions or safeguards on parenting time (including, where appropriate, requirements for supervision, the presence of another responsible adult, or limitations on overnights) as necessary to protect the child’s safety and welfare.
